column1: For purposes of this table, states were included if they mandated the listed actions. A number of states released guidance or recommendations related to the actions listed in this table but fell short of issuing a requirement and are thus not included.
* Bars are considered closed if they are closed to indoor and outdoor in-person service or indoor in-person service only; typically, bars remain open for takeout, delivery, and curbside pick up.

For historical data, including dates of state actions, please see our [GitHub](https://github.com/KFFData/COVID-19-Data/tree/kff_master/State%20Policy%20Actions/State%20Social%20Distancing%20Actions) page.
1. The category totals for state face covering requirements may sum to more than 51 as some states may impose more than one type of requirement.

2. Beginning Aug. 11, non-residents entering Alaska from another state or country must submit a travel declaration with a negative COVID-19 test result 72 hours prior to departure, arrive with proof of a qualifying negative test, or purchase a test upon arrival and self-quarantine.
3. The gathering ban listed for these states refers to the lowest indoor limit in a majority of the state; there are higher limits for outdoor or other settings.
4. California has closed restaurants except for carry out and delivery in regions with less than 15% of ICU capacity available. This currently impacts two out of five regions.

5. These states did not formally issue stay at home orders; however, other actions, including closing non-essential businesses, banning large gatherings, and issuing advisories urging residents to stay home, had the same effect. For these states, rolling back such measures is listed as easing/lifting the stay at home order.
6. Travelers to Hawaii may avoid the mandatory 14-day quarantine if they register with the state and have a negative COVID-19 test prior to departure.
7. Anyone entering a long-term care facility who is not a resident must wear a face mask.
8. New restrictions on large gatherings and restaurant and bar service in Illinois are requried in all regions in the state.
9. Any gathering of greater than 500 people must receive approval from the local health department.
10. Iowa limits gatherings to 50% of indoor or outdoor venue capacity and requires social distancing of 6 feet; if these requirements cannot be met, gatherings are limited to 10 people.

11. Face masks are required in indoor public spaces, state executive branch buildings, in bars and restaurants when not seated, and in other recreational venues (e.g., bowling alleys) when not seated to eat
12. Although the Governor has recommended pausing the move to phase out of the reopening plan, all businesses have reopened and the state has delegated decisionmaking authority to the local level.
13. Louisiana restricts venues to 50% capacity with a maximum of 250 people.
14. Indoor gatherings of up to 75 people are permitted or 25% of venue capacity; outdoor gatherings are limited to 150 people or 25% of venue capacity.
15. Maine provides exceptions to the mandatory traveler quarantine based on negative COVID test results or travel from certain states.
16. Massachusetts limits gatherings indoors to eight people per 1,000 square feet, not to be greater than 25 people, and gatherings outdoors to 25% of facility capacity, not to exceed 100 people.
17. Mississippi reimposed a face mask requirement for the general public in 61 of the state's 82 counties.
18. Face coverings are required in public indoor spaces and for organized outdoor activities when social distancing is not possible in counties with four or more active cases.

19. In Nebraska, groups at public venues are limited to no more than 8 people per table and venues that hold 500 or more people must get any reopening or capacity expansion plans approved by the local health department. Indoor venues are limited to 50% capacity.
20. In addition to employees, these states require patrons/visitors in limited sectors to wear face coverings.

21. In New York, areas that have a high density of cases are subject to stricter policies, including closure of non-essential businesses, smaller caps on large gatherings, bar closures, and restaurant restrictions. As of December 14, this impacts 26 areas.
22. Restaurants in New York City are closed to indoor dining. Outdoor dining, take out, and delivery are still permitted.
23. Public gatherings are limited to 50% of venue capacity. This does not apply to events at private residences.
24. Oklahoma requires people to wear face coverings on state property when social distancing cannot be maintained.
25. South Carolina restricts venues to 50% capacity with a maximum of 250 people.
26. Face coverings are required in government buildings, restaurants, and large gathering venues, but local officials have the authority to mandate face coverings in other public places.
27. TN has implemented less restrictive orders that allow non-essential businesses and restaurants to reopen in 89 of the state’s 95 counties.
28. Face masks required in counties with more than 20 COVID-19 cases.
29. Face masks are required in indoor public places, but are not required in businesses.

30. VA does not have a separate designation for bars, but bar areas of restaurants are closed, except for table seating. The on-site sale, consumption, and possession of alcohol is prohibited after 10:00 p.m.
31. All social distancing restrictions were lifted by a WI Supreme Court ruling, not a decision by the Governor.
